A true cornas, nice fruit and tannins
Long nice taste
Blackberry, plums spice with hints of brown sugar with nice soft tannin lingering finish.
Smoky, leathery, delicious wine. Needs more time to age
Balanced fruits full bodied wine. Light tanning with long finish. A slight peppery taste gives it a sparkle and a 'sense of difference' from CdR. A pleasant and surprising wine from the Ardeche
pepper earthy oak
Meaty and leathery. Barnyard. Floral. Still primary on the palate, showing ripe fruit. More polished compared to the other young Cornas that I have tried in the past. Pretty accessible right now.

Maybe waited a little to long to get to five stars. 
The old wine flavors of leather and cigar box are there, but the fruit is lacking. 
Still a wonderful wine with a steak.
(Bin 21)

Great discovery! Wine at first had a woody smell and tasted minerals..even salty I would say..over time, it started  changing and became a soft and elegant wine.. earthy, blackberry, cherry, oak, minerals were the dominant smells and tastes..loved the wine..not cheap definitely but worth every penny..

My first experience with a wine of this fine caliber from this region. Delicious! Jammy start with just the right amount of spices. Excellent soft mouth feel. Every sip felt like it was going to have thinning, chalk finish... but it did not! Stayed bold and full all the way to the back of the mouth and down the hatch.
Wonderful suggestion from Julian Bruell at L'Albatros in Cleveland.

Far too young to drink yet however I could not resist trying. This wine has depth, structure, a hint of pepper, great finish, is tannic and opulent. I would say very definitely Old World Syrah and very definitely not New World Shiraz. Drink it with food.

3.9@Wine dinner. Powerful & vivid, youthful Cornas. Syrah 100%. It displayed aromas of plum, blackberry, cherry, red currant, herbs, licorice, oak,  leathery, smoke, meaty,  earthy, pepper, exotic spices. Medium+ body with medium+ tannins & acidity.

I’ve taste already few vintages from this label, all of them were very nice.
Very good tipicity, well balanced.
Cherry, blackberry, clay, savory graphite, leather,black pepper and beautiful strong earthy notes.
Boom! Chocolate, vanilla, blueberries. Huge palate, more subdued nose. Young but still cracking. Liked it.

Drinkable, but a bit unbalanced. Thin, tannic, sour, a little sweet. Some nice fruity notes. A scent of tobacco, but doesn’t really come out in the flavour. I didn’t really love it before dinner or during (boeuf bourguignon), but then I had another glass the next night with a spicy mushroom taco and suddenly it was perfect! But that faded away as soon as I moved on to another taco.

I suspect this is a great wine for spicy food, but otherwise mediocre every other way I tried it.

4.2 - An amazing Cornas, exuding aromas of cherry, blackberry and plum mixed with delicate notes of smoke, vanilla and oak. Elegant and silky texture, good acidity complements harmoniously the fruit-laden profile, with lots of cherry tinged with notes of graphite, pepper and tangerine peel.

An extremely well balanced and structured Cornas expressing beautifully now. It's not overly expressive which one might find cloying with some other Northern Rhone Syrah. Black cherry, blackberry, anise, ginseng, cedar and white pepper all layering over each other nicely. Tannin is well integrated. Finish is unexpectedly short otherwise it would be a blockbuster.

4.0  Dark ruby, with dark red, blue and black fruit, and earth on the nose. Decanted and filtered about an hour before entrée. 10 years old and still going strong. Dry, m+ body, m acidity, 13% ABV, long & slow legs on the glass, m tannins, long finish. Blueberries, blackberries, vanilla, earth, a bit of anise and white pepper on the palate. Smooth tannins. Finishes with lingering fruit and spice. Paired with my BBQ marinated Rib Lamb Chops and then grilled, with side salad.

1 bottle decanted for an hour or so and the other bottle slow ox for half a day.
Very nice creamy vanilla oak mixed with red and black fruits aromatics. The decanted bottle had more fruits on the foreground while the slow ox bottle shows some secondary notes of herbs and leather. To me the nose fare better than the palate.
On day 2 the fruits on the palate faded more leaving the oak more pronounced.

(4.25) Very good Cornas, paired to my Entrecôte Beaurnaise. ‘Left over’ of evening with friends yesterday.

Very full and ripe, almost a Aussie, which was the first guess of them tasting blindly. Aromas of blackberries, plum, cassis, gravy, slight stone, black tea, still juicy and fresh in the nose. On the palate ripe and juicy black currants, blue berries, minty freshness, graphite, freshly grinded pepper, sweet spices, long sweet tobacco finish.

This is good. And refined. Really not far from a Hermitage. Expressive and fresh nose with aromas of cassis, dried plum, balsamic and black pepper. It s a palate coater with smooth texture, some density and spiciness, a long and fruity finish. Might gain in complexity with age.

Lovely ruby red edge and a maroon core! Aromas of dark fruit, caramel, hints of chocolate and spices with fennel being most apparent.  The palate is smooth with dark fruit, vanilla and spice leading to a long finish. Paired very well with hay smoked pigeon.

Perfect old world style of Syrah (Cornas). Dark fruits and minerals, un-decompressed complexity but extremely elegant and refined. Lower alcohol levels married with traditional approach made for such a beautiful wine. (Served blind).

Clear, medium ruby. Clean, medium plus intensity aroma of blackberry, black cherry, leather, earth and mint. Dry, high acidity, medium plus tannins, medium body and medium finish. Palate confirms the nose. Complex, well balanced, excellent quality. I enjoyed this at the Ultimate Northern Rhône Tasting Dinner July, 19, 2019.

Another excellent one from Voge. Very similar to 2005 Vieilles Fontaine but more apparent heat and extract with tad less acidity that renders it more forthcoming than its counterpart. Voluptuous and concentrated.

Exquiste! Well structured, intense & deeply complex. A non stop tornado of flavors constantly swirling bursts if red fruits, berrys, & more spice tgan a Morrocan Market. Full bodied & desert dry with rich powerful tannins in a nevrr fading lingering finish
More concentration but still lacking a bit of fruits to get to perfect balance.
Needs time IMO. A heavy weight.

Nose: oak, smoke,

Medium pluss tannines

Smoothly textured and go down from your palate to throat like a thin satin cloth. Light and soft, but doesn't feel wanting, well content. Good marriage with Chinese lightly seared scallop and squid.

3.8. 2nd attempt at this renowned Cornas.

Opaque purple. M(-) damson, ash, leather, black olives from the jar. M(+) alcohol, m. acid, m. tannin and body.  M(+) black cherry, damson jam and a fair amount of barrel spices with a hot finish.

It’s good, but still quite primary and  not yet as good and as complex as it should (and hopefully will) get.

I’ll leave the remaining bottles for another 5 years or so.

Alain Voge was among the leaders that revived Cornas - an appellation often underappreciated. Les Vieilles Vignes is their classic cuvée, which is also the oldest - from 60-year-old vines deeply rooted in granite soils. It might be the finest Syrahs of Rhône Valley I’ve tasted, with a powerful yet silky tannins, an earthy character along an extremely long finish. I can still recall their wonderful bouquet...
V nice - good window to approach this. Superb with roast beef and an hour to breathe

8/10 bit too young atm.

Syrah 2:8; corked unfortunately. 

This wine comes from 8-10 different parcels with 30-60 year old vines on decomposed granite slopes, locally called "gore". Manually harvested, it ages 18-20 mo in casks, 20% new. Can mature for 15 years. 

Alain Voge -started as a distiller in the late 50s- runs the family winery with Alberic Mazoyer; they own land in St. Péray and St. Joseph. 

Good volume despite the cork, ripe and intense, could still detect iron, lavender and rosemary. 

2012 was a hot year in Cornas.

Dark inky color. Complex nose giving off aromas of black pepper, anise and black & blue fruits. On the palate, jammy blueberry compote and black pepper with graphite and cola. Aged beautifully for a special occasion.

Dark garnet color of medium intensity color. Nose of black olives, grilled meat, black pepper. There is some red cherry in there but it is mostly tertiary now. On the palate, it is dry, with medium fine grained tannin, medium acidity. There is high flavor intensity but it feels lean. It has a solid structure but elegant mouthfeel. Notes of camp fire, garrigue and savory herbs pop on the palate. The finish is long, dry and savory. You can sit down and keep finding new notes for hours in this bottle.
leather, black fruit, spice, some distinctive tertiary notes (earthy); nice balance. Textbook Northern Rhône, beautifully aged. Nice now but absolutely no need to hurry if you have some bottles left.

Wow I finally understand why they love it so much in the US. Dark fruit bursting from the glass, almost smells like a Bordeaux not Syrah! On the palate very juicy and supple yet restrained at the same time. Very young but actually delicious now in my opinion. Glad I have 2 more.

Why I love Northern Rhone wines. Spice, floral notes, graphite, a finish that goes on for days. Built to last, will improve over next 5 years and drink well for 20 . Not sure I get the low ratings on here- must be looking for something other than a Cornas.

Several earthy notes combined with saline hues iodine, balsamic prunes and blackberries I think give a summary of the nose.Appreciated the thickness of the body,  while certain medicinal elements were a nice surprise. Balanced tannins acidity profile kept the desire for more alive. Other than this I believe that there are better if its kind.  Pleasant medium finish.  A 3.7
After one year in new barriques, it's powerful yet refined.
easy smooth and light great

Fruit forward, sour cherries & smokey . 
Not great length but a good winter wine
earthy pepper taste.
Fruity and earthy notes, Nice acidity. Perfect with French cheese and served medium chilled. Beautiful Rubin colored🍷
Good basic wine with full body and earthy tones. Not a lingering whine rather solid shorter full taste. Great value at 15€
Smooth,not too fruity and long on palate. Good value and v enjoyable.
Okay evening wine

Dark chocolate, blueberry, leather, mashroom.
Great balance. Good wine
Nice, heavy wine, goes well with spiced dishes and meat
Top wine thoroughly enjoyed over dinner with some great friends. We enjoyed a risotto and it complemented it delightfully
Bof
€15 in Carrefour. Light and easy drinking. My mate Sean likes it too. A solid 4 out of 5
d
Great wine
Nice wine
Full bodied with lovely earthy flavour
Well preserved although it is murky. Very plummy w elegant aromas derived from wood. Traditional style. Good acidity and round tannin .
Old but still going...rusty on the rim but dark red below ...still has ample nose of cassis leather oak and fruit still intact ...90

Saturday older wines day!

Seriously aged St Emilion of top pedigree…. And it is beautiful; mushrooms, cloves, dried fruits, leather, lots of complexity.

Acids and tannins still there securing a fine balance. Depth and complexity. Impressive. 18 pts @ winefields auctioneers
Surprisingly vivid fruit. Wine still red with a brownish edge only. Very nice smooth tannins. Definitely a great wine and great buy from Antique wines in Lyon.
leather oak plum blackberry earthy cherry blackcurrant vanilla mushroom chocolate dark fruit red fruit cassis cedar black fruit dark chocolate coffee licorice
Ruby with brick rim. Plum and leather nose. Mature evolved taste with ripe bing cherry pencil and leather. Peeking but will keep. Very nice
Great wine and tour in st emilion
Complex and big variety between vintages

Brick red. Dried fruit, fig and plum, tobacco and leather. still lot of fruit aroma left. Good body and structure, layered, good acidity level, slim, ripe tannins. Extremely good finish. Still lot of potential.

Dark red grenade color. Nice red fruit aromas with notes of oak and soft spices. Medium-bodied, quite well-balanced Bordeaux wine with a little overacidity but soft alcohol and tannins. An 86-88 pts wine.

30 years and still kicking! Deep red clear with light brown rim. Intense and complex nose of well hung meat, cigar box, licorice, cinnamon, mushroom, leather, forest floor and dried fruits (especially prune plum). There is so much going on here. 
On the palate it is obviously mature and developed in style, but at the same time very much alive with impressive acidic balance. Well integrated tannins. Sensational rich and deep, with a multidimensional and endless finish.

Maybe not the best wine we tasted, but certainly one of the most interesting! At first taste and nose was dominated by bonfire smoke, hickory and vanilla. With different type cheese tastes of blackcurrant, rasperry and plum was revealed. Taste was ever changing through the entire experience.

4.7. A pleasure to drink: smooth with still a light backbone of acidity that keeps it alive and surprisingly vibrant. Allspice, damp earth, smoky oak, incense, cinnamon, cherry/plum; with more time it develops notes of roasted coffee bean and hints of cacao. Amazing how this 35 years old keeps changing over time (and it needed around 1.5- 2 hours to open up). Medium-finish. Delicious.

Went 🍷 treasure hunting this weekend ; of course now need to make room.  So ‘05 Soutard is up.  Sunday timed for happy Bordeaux Sunday.  Vita/ JP better be proud
This is still a big palate 🕳 for me so take the note with a grain of sediment 😉 
Right bank: 70% merlot/30% CF 
Spiced up nose/ cedar/ plum
Nice palate attack. Baked spiced plum/ cassis / fruitcake-with a licorice lick at the finish. Has mid-palate adds of tobacco/herb. Drinking effortlessly 1hour decant. Perfect dusty tannins.Good finish. 4.25 ⭐️🆙

An ok wine from Saint-Émilion with its great blends with such as Merlot as the dominated one. A delicious taste of plum, tobacco and some oak. Just a typical Bordeaux was my first thoughts, but its aftertaste of the tannins was round and sweet by vanilla.

⭐ 4,4 / 5
🎯 87 / 100
🍷 Full bodied

1985: Maraschino cherry, garden herbs, stewed and jammy fruits, baked earthy, tangy raisins without the sweetness. For such an old wine it's still very lively. Mouth coating silky tannins and lovely weighty texture.

Region: Saint-Emilion
Grape Variety: Bordeaux Blend Red
ABV: 13.5%
Stopper: Cork

Full bodied red wine.
Intense red with purple reflections in colour, on the nose, aromas of plum and blackberry with notes of spices. Medium tannins. Well-balanced in acidity. Savory and classic red wine in style. On the palate, dry, rich, flavourful, oaky, smokey, fruit-driven, hint of black pepper and wood, touch of tobacco, delivers red fruits character, jammy, fleshy, still young, lengthy, soft. It has a long finish.

Medium/deep garnet. Medium intensity nose which still has elements of blackcurrant, blackberries and black plum. Beautyfully integrated oak with subtle vanilla notes, sweet spice and hints of oak. Main nose has some deeper elements of meaty and cedar character. Slightly herbaceus; equalyptic. After sometime in the glass sweet tobacco reveals itself. Palate medium plus acidity, extreme soft yet powerful tannins. Full body. Flavours are marure, meaty, subtle oak, herbaceus. Finish is long and intense. Complex

Wasnt expecting a huge amount, but I was taken back and totally charmed by this littleknown Pomerl, proving old right banks can provide great joy. 

An interesting dusty maturity, but its juicy at the core and full of flair. Plum skin, red currant, potpourri, bombay mix.

Layered, very long with fully integrated tannins. Whilst it's delicate, it should stay at this peak stage for a little longer.

A positive surprise. A bit closed at first, but opens up after a while and becomes truly delicious for a few hours. Somewhat strange aromas, but has impressive concentration and length. Not much tannins left, but will last for a few more years.

Celebrating the delivery of a study 1 week ahead of schedule 👌😎. Lovely 34 years old Bordeaux 😋.  Deep garnet color. Dominant tertiary aromas  with blue cheese notes at the begining with red & black fruit undertones. After 2 hour decanting wine start to bloom delivering aromas of tobacco,cedar, leather, black cherry,black plums, dried blackcurrant, dried bay leaves, notes of molasses, hints of roasted coffe & green pepper corn. Palate is medium bodoed. It follows the nose with a black & red fruit core...

Very excited about trying this 30 year old, and I can safely say it delivered. Aromas of black dried cherries, barn, dyttere earth, dried wood, vanilla. It is still somewhat fresh, gives good presence of fruitness, though it is of course much more rounded than a younger cuvee would. Full bodied with perfectly balanced tannins and acidity, long pleasant finish, and it suited our moose Entrecôte just great. I'm glad I got hold of 5 other bottles ☺
Just by looking at the colour you already know this wine has developed lots of tertiary flavours: earthy, leather, truffle, cocoa etc., smooth and nice with roast beef <3

Some wine stone. Deep red with dark core. Concentrated, rich dark fruit. Light barrel, hint of vanilla and concentrated black currant character. Palette of concentrated dark fruit, delichious balanced acidity, integrated tannins, light barrel. Such concentration and rich, sweet fruit of dark berries. Balanced acidity and so complex and smoothe. Long finish.

Great Bordeaux.

Martin the maître d blessed us with a bottle of the 1986. My wife's year of birth. Don't make me choose. I love my wife and nothing will ever come between us. This wine, placed directly between us, was an absolute sensation. Deep, rich, fulfilling. We were warned that the bottle was on the edge, but that's how I live

A 1986 St Emilion Grand Cru! Jitters gave way to relief then delight as this wine proved to still be fresh with surprising bite that mellows into velvety notes of mushroom, earthiness, leather, black tea grind, blackberry, and plum with a long, lingering finish! A real treat!
DFWE - showing really well. Tertiary and vegetal flavours in abundance. Long finish. Definitely would buy a bottle of this. 4.25
Deeper notes than the second label, fruity and bit more well balanced. Nice bottle, but will probably open up more after a few more years maturing
Right bank...still jammy in this one, plus some herbs, mint, and capsicum. Kind of reminds me of some of Southern Rhone stuff
Merlot driven, fruity with luscious tannins rounding out the mouth. Beautiful nose combining a blend deep red and dried black fruit. Lovely wine.
Nice balance. Decent nose and matched on the pallet. Good amount of dark fruit and light oak. Medium tannins and soft finish.
4.2 Very deep and good Grand Cru Classe.2014 was a good year for the producer. Med to full body, amazing floral nose and long finish
It’s too young at the moment but excited with the Magnum I brought. Will try to leave it for 10 years minimum. Might struggle though!

This was from the cellar and it held up. 70% merlot; 30% cabernet franc. Supple tannins. Ripe plum, black cherry, anise. 
Recommend.
4.3* My Birthyear wine on my Birthday...brought back from the Chateau itself👍😁 point extra for the sentimental value👊🤩 cheers every1🍷🍇
Bright red and purple colour.  Nose aromas of plum and blackberry with notes of spices.  Dry, oaky, rich and smoke.  Needs more age.
Really nice 2005. Good structure.  leather oak earthy plum raisin.  plum blackberry cocoa black fruit vanilla red fruit cinnamon taste.

4.5 nicely aged.

The nose is relatively plain with plum, woody and spices notes, compared with its flavors.

The medium plus bodied 1986 possesses a soft and well aged tannins that coats the palate gracefully. Also the tannins balances and complements by mellowed yet vivid acidity giving the mouth a refine texture. 

The aftertaste is lingering and pleasant with woody notes and a hint of dark chocolate. 

70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet franc
Classic St Emilion, impressively developed, probably better than ever.
90p. Almost over the top.
Merlot and Cab Franc- dries fruits and earthy.  Earthy. Very nice indeed
so tart and delicious
For a 32 year old wine it had an amazing very smooth taste, very little nose, great color, light fruit taste

Cork needed the Durand. But came out in two pieces. A bit off-putting on first taste but quickly came around - even the color improved. Tasted mature but not old. Fruit still lovely, tannins very much softened. I think my “shot” at buying this at auction was very well rewarded.  Great pair with grilled veal chops.
Incredible wine. Still so much alive and it even needs some air before it kicks in

Bought at the vineyard and a wonderful story.....Thanks for sharing Joris!
Neat character. Lots of red currants dotted over moss in the forest on a early morning.
Balanced between light vanilla pepper blackcurrant essence with the perfect French earthy finish expected from a Sant-Emilion Grand Cru
Very nice. Decanted about 2 hours. Elegant and complex. Aromas of blackberry, dark plum, red currant. Hints of tobacco and soil. Smooth soft tannins, medium body.
Plums and leather in aromas, full of sweetness. Great finish with earthy, fruity and chocolate background. Well balanced, blend of Merlot and Cabernet Franc.
Little below a 4.0.  Dark purple.  Light aroma.  Med body with apparent dark chocolate on the palate. Tannin isnt low.  This wine can and needs to age for 10 more yrs.
Brick color, red currant, plum, hint of woody. Medium palate, tannin is smooth but not velvety . Medium length . Overall, not a big wine , smooth and enjoyable !
Earthy, mushroom, cedar, game. A lot of tertiary notes but still balanced with dark berries. Smooth, flavourful and lonnnng finish. It just gets better with the hour!
Ripe black fruit. Lots of oak and vanilla. Leather. Medium to full body and medium tannines. Velvety mouthfeel and very long finish. Great wine. 4.1
Bouquet of dark chocolate and spice.  Mouthfeel has medium high acidity, full body, and flavors of chocolate, some black cherry, and some background spice.
1985 in 2020 | Great, pencil, soil, leaves. Tannins integrated and in ok shape.
Good wine, dried fruit, Oak, leather, smoke, vanilla, leather and earth
Great wine, perfectly balanced and aged flawlessly so far. Great tastes of  plum blackberry earthy leather smoke oak. Great with cheese or red meat. Paired perfectly with roast duck
Fully matured grand cru classé. Soft, fruity and with round tannins giving the wine another one to two years. Cassis and red berries. Superb and yessss .... four bottles left in the cellar.
This is a great example of an integrated aged bordeaux.  Its smooth and velvety.  It may be a little bit past its absolute best but it lovely all the same.   Scrummy Soutard.

3.9 Wonderful balance of red fruits bouquet, gentle acidity, hints of vanilla and sweet species. Non pretentious pleasure.
Nose: 3
Color: 4
Integrity: 5
Taste: 4
Length: 3+
A 2005 which is living up its expectations! Nice nose, complex body with very pleasant structure. Well rounded and silky this is a beautiful wine that reaches its maturity and is ready to drink now.

Flavours of leather, forest floor, sour cherry, smoke, barn yard.

Long finish. Very good wine.
Ruby colour with little browning. Slightly sweet blackcurrant / stewed plums on the nose. Gorgeous fresh black fruit upfront on the palate with silky smooth tannins and Lovely vanilla edged length.

92 pts. Blackcurrant, oak, vanilla and lots of coffee notes. Good complexity compared to it's young age. Round tannins and a fine acidity.
Drink this now and the next 10 years.
Open and pour. Very nicely integrated tannins. Slight spice on the finish and notes of Blackberry, cassis and tobacco. A really beautiful wine and still one of my favourite st emillion.
Bright cherry on the nose, smooth, very minerally and too lean (at least for my taste) on the palate. Perhaps needed longer aeration, still not the best vintage of Soutard that I’ve tried.
This year is a primarily merlot with large amount of cab frank. Perfumie almost sweet on the nose. Well balanced soft tannis and fruit on the pallete. Softer then a traditional bordeaux.
Herbs pepper mineral m bodied mild tannin
Delicious. Still got some fruit
St-Emilion trip 2019. Delicious, balanced wine, smoky/leathery if I recall with dark fruit. Look back fondly now to the annoying Aussie tourist complaining about lack of Shiraz.
2016 vintage- Well rounded, nice acidity and tanins, cherry and red fruit aromas with a nice well balanced finish. Should be aged a few more years before opened
The first wine of the night. I believe this was from the the right bank of the region, an excellent soft aged wine with light but flavoursome flavours.

Lovely bdx. 
Musty nose.
Fruity on pallate but not overpowering. Extremely well balanced, delicious bdx, smooth tannins, just a smooth bdx experience. A fine wine. What more to say about  a 2000 bdx! Lovely stuff, paired with roast lamb. Mmm. 😃🍷🍷🍷

Exceptional St Emillion. Maybe too young but great potential. Forest fruits, cassis, dried herbs, licorice, hazelnut, green pepper, cedar and tobacco. Medium + body, acidity and tannins. Pairing with red meats. Will be developing.

Nice nose with brick red color in periphery! Slightly tannic but got better later, even after a day! Always pleasure to drink this wine.  It's my probably 20th and last bottle.  Will definitely miss this wine since it will be nearly impossible to find the same cintage.  Dry and yet acidic!  Nice balance.  Not muchberry aroma, but complex and pleasant smell.  It is made of merlot all right!

Beautifully aged Wine from Saint-Émilion. 

Color is classic red with a darker core. The nose is earthy with little fruit.
On the palate the wine is seriously balanced with still vibrant tannis and nicely imbedded acids. The finish is of stunning lengths.
The wine is at its peak or just seconds after... 

The Wine gets better after every sip. Changed to 4.5 !!!

Drinking well but some way to go before showing it’s true beauty. Lots of dark and red fruits - cherry and plum with bramble and cassis notes. Lovely background of oak and earthy notes with cured tobacco and leathery notes. Good flavour profile and amplitude - needs time to soften and really shine. Dry, full bodied, medium acidity and tannins with decent finish. Overall, lovely wine with potential to be 4.5🌟

Wonderful Saint-Émilion with a dark purple color in the aroma and taste, mainly dark fruit in the background red fruit and dried fig prune raisins notes of oak vanilla chocolate coffee tobacco cocoa graphite leather earthy smoke mushrooms forest floor cinnamon licorice pepper.  Bordeaux is perfectly balanced with high acidity, velvety tannin, long fruity finish, great solo wine.  🍇🍷🍷👍🏻😃👌🏻

I was wondering whether the 2002 still keeps in a good condition or not, as I have not kept it in a proper cellar, since I brought it back from St-Emilion in 2015.  

Fortunately. It was still in a good shape.  The nose shows notes of blackberry, plum and milk chocolate.  The palate is with medium to full body, soft light tannins and balanced acidity.  However. I guess I should have opened the bottle earlier.  My fault.

Vertical Tasting at the Chateau Soutard. I forgot to take pictures so I will use the Vivino’s. 2014 is already showing sines of age but still delicious. Maybe won’t last too long. leather plum blackberry oak cherry dark fruit cedar

My novice nose may be too quick to give a four. There however was a softness to it like velvet to the tongue. You can truly taste the grapes. A hint of black currant gave me a bit of a fruity fix. A lovely starter.

Earthy nose with spicy twist of herb mix. Fairly tannic, yet shows surprisingly fresh and wealthy flavor of black fruit with a lick of bitter chocolate and fine peppery kick. Solid finish exudes a sense of grace. Long life indeed.

Great bright colour, showing good age at the edges.
Clean and bright nose, drinking really nicely with some good depth of fruit.
Starting to show nice complexity and will likely improve rapidly over the next few years.

91 pts. Dark crimson red. A good balance between classic and modern style quite fruit driven but not to concentrated a bit leather and fresh pepper dark chocolate and black cherry full bodied with soft textured tannins and long finish

Fruity with a short lingering on the palette.
Boysenberry and mint chocolate.
Good depth and typically a little dry due to the grape mixture. 
Opens up nicely after a while with lots more dark berry molasses and dry sage.
Nice drop.

This seems to be getting close to the limit. The cork crumbled on opening but the wine is in great shape. A meatiness has developed that wasn’t there before but the fruit still shines through. My last bottle....

A step down from two previous bottles.. this one quite austere and having shed some fruit more earthy and leather than the fine plum and dark fruits. Perhaps in hibernation or starting a gentle decline. Went well with braaied kudu fillet.

Bought this At The vineyard paid 84$ can for it. Found it on Internet in France for 50$. It's beautiful very well balance great potential for aging. Would pay 115$ if you can make the trip to get it !

an 18 y/o barnyard nose reminiscent of a leaking pipe in a loo.. bursting sweet cassis and blueberries after a 45min decant.. hint of herbs and underlying plums and cedar in the elegant palate with good intensity and length.. what a joy with the japanese beef stew i had for dinner! drink now!

Entering its drinking window.
Dark ruby with some bricking. Decent aromas of black cherry, plum, leather, earth, mushroom, wet leaves, tobacco and coffee bean. Good layers on the palate with complex fruit concentration, mouth coating velvety tannins and balancing pleasant acidity.
Enjoyable.

Very nice easy going grand cru classe. 2003 was a very hot year and some have mentioned its evident in this bottle i agree to an extent. The fruit is standard blackberry and tobacco and coffee seem to come through also its slightly woody,  there is a distinct chestnuty finish.

This chateau has no relationship with Soutard-Cadet, maybe once centuries ago? Made with 63 % Merlot, 28% Cabernet Franc, 7 % Cabernet Sauvignon and 2 % Malbec, yes, Malbec was once dominating in Bordeaux; opaque purple burgundy color with nose of baking spices, ash, graphite, cinnamon, nutmeg, clove, licorice, hazelnut, black cherry & blackberry, firm tannin with balanced acidity and full lush body, fruits forward with black cherry, blackberry, plum and fig, finishes with black pepper, licorice and cacao.

On the nose a touch of wood, slightly fruity; generous in the mouth, but medium-bodied with well integrated tannins, red fruit and a beautiful bright finish. 

This is drinking really well now but don't leave it too much longer. It won't need long in the decanter either!

4.0*
Nice aged 12 years old St. Émilion I enjoyed paired with aged beef meat steak.

🍇: 70% Merlot and 30% CF

👃: Medium intense aromas with bouquets of plum, blackberry, mushroom, leather, earth and hint of tobacco were on the nose.

👄: I predicted the tannin would be still prominent, but actually the wine was silky and round enough already on the palate with firm acidity. The structure and complexity were good and they contributed to realize multi-layered savoury dark fruit flavor on the palate.

Finale of our golden oldies tasting and the youngest. In that sense really other feel than some of the other reds 10-20 years olders. Harder, sharper.

Nevertheless in its own right good stuff. In the nose cassis, nice berry fruit. On the palate juicy fruit like cassis, raspberry and plum, quite herbaceous, aprika, bread, and a smoky finish of toast and coffee.

Dark purple color. Very expressive & wide range of fruit aromas . Minerality of graphite. Assemblage Merlot/CabFr - 70/30. This wine demonstrates slow evolution and has a great cellar potential. I would revisit it in 5 years. This is the meditative kind of wine you want to spend some time with. 35 years old vines. MLF of 80% of the grapes in new barriques. Aged ~18 months in barriques (70% new). History of Chateau dates back in 16th century. Soutard is known for its Merlot-dominant red wine.
Rating 4,1/5

St-Emilion GC tasting wine 26 : The only 2012 in the tasting. Tobacco, cedar, charcoal, truffle, spices ... all supported by fruit. Working the glass adds a delightful touch of mocha. Rich palate, medium to full-bodied, well balanced with, almost silky were it not for the tannins who are still very present. Cherries from start till finish.

Managed to get a hold of this St Emilion 1989 vintage. Not your typical Bordeaux blend, as it comes with smaller amount of Merlot in it. However, nice and well-structured one with blackcurrant and plum on the nose. Hints of leather making a way to quite earthy taste, which keeps lingering for a while. Excellent wine overall

Ruby red with garnet rim.
Nose of black currant, licorice, bilberry, dark cherry, plum, chocolate, anise, pepper, cedar.
Palate of soft but grippy tannins, med plus acidity, med bodied, laced with red and dark berries, licorice, chocolate, pepper and some stalky note.
A nice St Emilion which still has more potential to offer.

Expressive bouquet that blends fresh black fruit w/ floral & savory notes. Instantly enticing plum, cassis & mulberry develop into violet & lilac perfumes, ultimately exuding dried herbs, vanilla, new leather, cedar, mushroom & tobacco. 

Delicious & balanced, rich in flavor while medium-bodied, rounded mouthfeel with moderate plush, sweet tannins, a jolt of acidity & exciting vanilla finish, nice length. 

Pleasure right now, potential great in the making. Scoring a case to try gradually over the years  🍇📦

Another lovely 2000 vintage bordeaux. 63/28/7/2 blend of merlot/cab franc/cab sauv/malbec.

Medium ruby color. Nose has classic plummy and licorice notes, with hints of mushroom, cassis, and leather.

Palate shows blackberry, plum, slight bell pepper, slate, and rosemary flavors.

Slightly austere acidity and well integrated tannin. Slightly short finish but drinking well right now. 13.5% abv.

2000
(Cork broke )
👀 deep garnet ( almost no signs of aging) 
👃🏼 Med + intensity , fully developpped , blackcurrant, black plum, prune , vanilla, nutmeg, chocolate , dried cranberry earth , leather 
👄 Med + acidity , Med + tannins (well integrated) , full bodied, Med flavor intensity , very long finish 
Very good wine , drink now 
Pairing with sirloin

Vintage & dark ruby red color together with blackberry, bing cherry, tobacco, dark chocolate, and hint of peppery spices on the nose & palate. Medium-bodied, fine tannins, sexy acidity, and soft & long aftertaste at the end. Nice balance & sexy taste.

Medium intensity on the nose, garnet in colour. Chalky tannin with medium alcohol. Great balance. Black fruit like blueberry, black currant are present along with spice and eucalyptus with slightly earthy touch. It’s significantly fruitier than the left bank. An obvious right bank.

Dry, tannic, very well blended berries / fruit on the palate and nose!  Great, long finish! Super wine!  At it’s minimum age.  Can drink now, will age.  Very unique, highly recommend!  Cheers Vivino friends!

Voluptuous smell, blackberry, vanilla, some oak, some prunes, tobacco and a slight cranberry. Taste is surprising. Medium tannins, probably because of the quirky grape composition: 63% merlot, 28% cab franc, 8% cab sauv and 1% malbec. Full flavors, tobacco, occasionally some pepper, blackberry, slight bay leaf with an overripe cherry throughout. Awesome red with my roasted pork and baked potatoes, love it.

Came out quite purple tinged in the glass but settled into a deep ruby in the decanter. Big wine which started out tight with high tannins and notes of cassis and herbal undertones. Opened up after a half hour and developed notes of ripe cherry. Very nice but best paired with food

Very rich aroma, hardly to separate but very intensed. However taste is not that rich
Eye: browner ruby
Nose: rubber, chocolate, soapy notes
Acidity: low
Taste: chocolate, jam, mint, eucalyptus, iodine

A cheap "off year" makes for a great bargain if left to decant for a few hours. When first opened the nose was sour and dry, but eventually opened up to more classic right bank oak, vanilla, cherry jam with fine lingering tannins.

Very generous 😷🔒⤵️gift from Vivino buddy and all round good guy @[1|8345227|WinoMutt]. 70% Merlot, 30% Cabernet Franc aged 18mths in French oak. Semi translucent dark cherry red with delicious nose of cedar, leather, plum & cassis. Dry, medium+ acidity with medium body, fine, dusty tannins &13.5% abv. Flavours of plum, cassis, tobacco & a touch of liquorice. Really good length finish. My kind of wine.4.3⭐. Perfect with roast beef & all the trimmings. Some life in this old dog yet I reckon. Thanks 🍷o🐕HBS

3.8 :) a bit overrated, 3.7 to be fair, but age is appreciated. Bit of barnyard in first nose than comes with apple/ peach compote/juice. Taste mainly plum  and cherry with some Greek nuts. Overall good.

Thought I'd finished my dozen of these but then stumbled across this in the cellar. What an absolute joy - felt a bit more youthful than the previous couple of bottles which were starting to show a bit of age. This was still a deep ruby colour and in the form of its life. Red cherry, cinnamon, leather, cedar on the nose. Black cherry, plum, nutmeg, blackberry palate. Tannins like creased old leather and that fresh, food-friendly acidity. A beautiful encore.

Fun to try an 'off' vintage Bordeaux with a few years on it. Red plums, some cranberry. Lots of tertiary notes, earthy, mushroom, forest floor. Popped and poured which was the only option given travel, perhaps some time would have opened up a bit but still enjoyable.

Soft nose, cigar box and red fruits,  smooth with dry aftertaste, dark cherry, hint of dark chocolate and vanilla. Has 1% Malbec in the blend which adds complexity. Big wine, will age well and should be decantered.
Really enjoyed at Popy and Florian’s house
32 years and still alive. Impressive. 92p
tobacco oak leather black fruit

Reliable bottle as I inch towards 100th. 

A old winery which offer good value wines. Notes of dark fruits , earthy aromas. A good mineral backbone which indicates quality Medium finishing with a elegant nose. This is not a flashy bottle but a workhorse wine like a discipline master no nonsense taken.

From a rather large plot of 30 hectare comes this high density Saint-Emillion with loads of structure, spices and a chocolate note. 

Somewhat more robust than the Larmande tasted side-by-side, which Soutard owns.

Great prospect.

#ugcb2019 - short note

The End.

Fragrant dark berries, chocolate and touch of leather. Quite full bodied for St Emilion, but the vintage was just like that. Almost juicy on the palate but certainly has a Bordelaise grip of powdery tannins. Ling savoury finish. 4

Fine & ripe!
Aromas of dried fruits, brick cellar, tobacco.
Dried strawberries, plum, ripe black cherries, cassis. tobacco, some vanilla, dark chocolate, some smoke, licorice, anise, pepper, coffee. 
Surprising acidity, good concentration, good length, smoooth tannins, smooth as butter.
92p

A classic Bordeaux nose - lots of sweet fruit and charm but not that much oomph. Lots of black plums, sugared coffee, and some smokey notes. A lovely nose!
Taste is mature, round and sweet with fine notes of red fruits, and a dash of spice. The finish is on the dry side but there is no arguing about the charm of this perfectly mature wine.

When one went through so many bottles of wine every year one can be pleasantly surprised or suitably impressed but rarely does one get stupefied, err...meaning opening your mouth in anticipation of more and more of this St. Emilion that taste, smell and look like a ripe dark cherry with light ruby voile on the rim. The pleasure lasted for nearly four hours, and if not for a weak stomach one may want to swallow the wine bottle to continue with the sensual gratification. Excellent wine.

Magic. Will be enjoyed on this Christmas Eve. 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon. Elegant, well developed - not a slight over the top and will last another few years. Juicy and refreshing. Dried fruit and plum. Blackberry and blackcurrant. Light pencil notes. Light barrel.Good acidity and length.

3 stars by itself, but much better with steak!

Chateau Soutard is a notable wine producer who has been making great value Clarets since 2009. This bottle of 2012 from their cellar showed some maturity already, and it’s an alarm for the age-ability of 2012. Hints of leather, lighter fruits than 15, (Yes, 15 Soutard is good!), ripe silky smooth tannins, sweet merlot fruits. Fair length finish with some mocha and spices. Drink before 2022.

Blend of Merlot , Cabernet Franc , Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec from Saint-Émilion, Bordeaux, France. Notes of blackberry, plum, cassis, blackcurrant, tobacco, leather, spices and mushroom. Full body, medium acidity, soft tannins, long aftertaste

Decanted 2 hours. Enjoyed with friends for their inaugural pizza oven night. Lots going on here. Dark berries, black pepper, mint, eucalyptus and earthy mineral notes. Soft tannins. Well structured. Delicious.

Superb St-Emilion that delivers emotions and almost did not move since last drinking 10y ago. Still feels in a great drinking window. 
👁️: Deep Garnet
👃: High intensity flavours of blackberry, blackcurrant, blueberry jam, leather, cedar. 
👄: Dry with medium acidity, medium tannins, medium alcohol, full body and long length.
⏳: Can drink now and in the next 3-5 years

Beautiful Bordeaux. Present from Matt H enjoyed with him and Sebastian S in London Nov 2021. Pronounced nose of damsons, blackberries, graphite and mint. Very good quality. Could have been a bit more intense, but beautifully balanced between fruit, tannins and acidity, very long finish, and layers of complexity.

The perennial thorn: What to drink with sausage and mash? Here’s one answer. Damson, raspberry, red currant acidity. Underlying sweetness. Soft tannins. Amazing length. Complexity enhanced as it aired.
Don’t make those saussos too spicy!

Drank in 2022. Now 10 years old. Starting to show its age. The tanins well and truly front up. Not ‘corked.’ First sip of the bottle was acidic. Helped obviously with decanting. The heaviness meant I kept it back until serving late in the dinner with pork, brisket. If you have this in cellar. Drink now before it’s too late.
Dry, soft tannins, the nose makes me feel like I’m entering a furniture shop, refined leather, cedar, medium finish. Wonderful!

What a nose. Deep and dark plum character coming through with graphite and cherry rounding off the nose. Still smells quite fruit forward, even after ~16 years. Touch of cassis comes through on the palette alongside a macerated cherry note which is just lovely. Tannins perfectly integrated and acid still slightly present but otherwise settled. Hints of cedar and tobacco leaf on the nose as it opens. Long finish of cranberry and mushroom/earth. 4.75

Clear, deep ruby, very fruity, black pepper spices, tobacco, oak, cloves; developing; v acidic, med   tannin, great potential for aging! Black currant, ripe cherries, tobacco, cocoa after taste, earthy, waste to drink now, shld wait for 10 yrs

Black fruit, liquorice, menthol on the nose, with a supple attack and black fruit development with brambles and liquorice. Velvety mouthfeel and medium finish with soft tannins. Well balanced. Great value older vintages at the chateau too!

Powerful Saint-Emilion. Opened for 5 hours before serving and still had some sharpness. Slight musk on the nose but ripe fruit and wood coming through. Needs a little more time for things to fully fall into place

Deep dark inky color with aromas of raspberries, blackberries, bread, and oats. Full bodied with hints of blackberries, blackcurrants, spice, and plums. Firm tannins and powerful with firm tannins. Still very young. Nice and long spicy finish

Blend of 70% merlot and 30% Cabernet franc. Aromas of dried fruit (raisin, prune), soft earth. Palate is fruit driven (tart) with red fruit and black fruit and some pepper at the back. Silky smooth. Surprised there’s still life left considering the reviews on CT. Special vintage for a milestone.

4.1

92-93/100, 4,3*

This St. Emilion Grand Cru has two stories to tell. One hour after decanting it is a superb wine in all aspects. Elegant nose, balance and complex with a great mix of fruit, spice and wood. As times goes by a second less pretty story unfolds and the wine becomes very mineral, with the fruit rapidly diminishing. Overall a very good wine that matched a Spanish “cocido” very well.

(3.9) ‘Passed this Chateau Soutard many times while driving to the old (and touristic) village of St. Emillion but never stopped there. Now it’s in my glass and I noticed some remarkable aroma’s. It’s seems a bit more earthy than usual in this area. Almost a bit modest compared to the neighbour wines. Probably due to the rather high amount of Cabernet Franc.’

🛠13%Alc 🍇65%ML/30%CF/4%CS/1%MB
🛒60€, UGCB

Today, I saved an old Soutard, native of SE.
Layed since 21 years waiting an enthusiast to appreciate his qualities.
Luckily, I found him on time, still alive, giving signs of tiredness.. Well, his tannins are not juvenile & powerful any more, polished by aging, but you can enjoy oddle of third aromas, earth, grilled bread, green bell, exotic spices, arrounded by confit blackcherry. Regarding his low acidity, don't expect him to evolve nicely, so if you like old style, you too, you can do a good deed ;) 3.8

3.8. Chateau Sautard is the oldest one in Saint-Emilion since 1762. It is also famous as long-lived wine and opening this vintage is obviously too early. Dark ruby, garnet, purple, strong tannin, fruity. Sri Lanka Italian restaurant. Tasted with pizza.

Intense aromas of leather, toasted tobacco and black berries. Medium bodied, medium acidity. Flavours of dark cherries, white pepper, slky smooth tannins and a constant, very long lingering finish.
Not extremely complex, yet high quality & easy drinking wine that would go amazingly with tender red meats.

Emilion vineyard of Chateau Soutard is planted to 63% Merlot, 28% Cabernet Franc, 7% Cabernet Sauvignon and 2% Malbec. ... The vineyard is planted to a vine density of 6,500 vines per hectare. The wine is vinified in gleaming, new, stainless steel vats of various sizes.

LastBottle: Like skydiving into a Grand Canyon of black fruits, incense, mint, flowers, truffle and black currant, the brain struggles to take it all in. Rich, plush, mouthcoating, but not heavy…

Me: somehow I’ve made it through four bottles of this and have yet to post a review.

Did not get at a super discounted price but this is a really nice one.

We were expecting much more from this bottle, but probably we missed the right time to drink it. So our fault. Any way it's still possible to notice its complexity. Light body and light aromas. Very dry and not persistent. Better lucky with a younger bottle. This was our first Gran Cru Classé. Still celebrating 12 years of marriage and now the Germany victory! ;-)

Need a bit of time to open up. Red fruit, chocolate and almond on the nose. I still think this bottle ages quite well with the dark ruby color and good scent after 30 mins of decant. A bit spicy in the taste, could be strong to some folks but ok to me to wash down a steak. Drink this together with the Argentinian top wine so unfortunately this one comes out short in comparison, less balanced, lower quality tannin and less visible finish.

‘05 vintage. Revisited 2 months on, this did not shine the way it did previously. Strong red tannins with features of red cherry, red currant jam and boysenberry. High acidity and high tannins with moderate fruit structure to support. pencil shavings and tobacco on the finish. Developed well over 1-2 hours , comprising a range of earthy mushroom notes. 3.8 at best, I had expected more.

Tight grippy tannins

Nose was initially understated and tight but took some 1+h to open up. Black fruits and sl leathery big bold mouthfeel... tannins still evident with still persistent freshness although the mid palate was not spectacular. Shortish length with sl sour spicy finish.

Dinner with Chris, Stephen & Roy at 新斗記.  
Chris's selection.
Ruby color.  Nose of floral, blackberry, plum, coffee, tobacco and licorice.  Ripe black fruits, pepper, cocoa and vanilla on the palate.  Medium bodied.

(3.7) Old gentlemen's tasting with dear friends. The youngest one of the bunch.

Nose with red fruit, vanilla & toast and lard. Medium acidity, red fruit, metal, pencil, little tanines, camphor, cedar, pomegranate and lavas. Fresh & young.

Let breathe for 20 minutes. 12yo
Colour: Hazy deep tawny/brown.
Nose: Pronounced notes of dried fig, mixed with plum and blackberry, hints of earthiness and oak, chocolate. Hints of lily and floral aromas.
Palate: Fully bodied, easy drinking, high acidity and dry. Starts with dark and dried fruits, leads to hints of mushroom and forest floor, then to oak and chocolate. Quite tart because didnt decant sediments properly. Medium long bitter leafy finish. Medium amounts of dry grippy tannins.

Alright. 85p.

My second stab at this wine, which has a hard act to follow vs the Cyril..and it feels like a step down. Initial notes of tobacco on the nose and earthy minerality on the palate. At aged 21 this is very smooth but is still holding up. This is due to the underlying acidity which is still evident. That said, I’d probably advise to drink now, as I don’t see it improving. A decent enough wine and the 3.5⭐️ awarded a couple of years back feels about right. I’ve probably had better for £37 though.

4.2 ⭐️ Classic bold St. Emilion.
Deep ruby in glass. The nose is rich and classic with hints of cherry, cassis, vanilla, oak, leather, bacon fat, forest floor, blackberry. Full body, dry, velvet texture, moderate acidity. The taste is noble with hints of cherry, cassis, blueberry, blackberry, coffee, earthy notes. Tannins are medium intense and medium lasting. Overall, classic, well done St.Emilion, bold, delicate and noble.

11.12.2016 TastedBlind - Red fruit nose with some cola and bubblegum notes with its soft acid and tannins made me picked it as a CdP

Salty again for 05! Mushroom, earthy, soy sauce and very concentrated on the nose; mushroom, dark fruit and tobacco and oaky and hint savory on the palate. There are still a lot going on and need to be developed! Keep it in the cellar for another 3/5 yr and see the difference!

I don’t think the 2014 is ready.
still fruity, fresh red berry mixed with black berry flavour and quite smoky for me and vanilla flavour
the taste is  bit rough. the tannins need more time to calm down. medium high tannin medium alcohol medium acidity
aftertaste is quite consistent and medium long

Color is deep purple with a light gradation to ruby at rim. Slow tears. On the nose, blackberry, plum, alcohol, charcoal, cocoa. On the palate, much less bold and dark. Fruit is tighter but still pleasant - plum, black currant. Finish a touch too acidic for me. Medium soft tannins

Really enjoying it.  Retaste 12/22/14.  Not enjoying as much as last time. Seems a bit maserated, more prunes, not so fresh.  However, nice acidity and well balanced.  More a 3 to me, so I will split the difference and change to 3.5.

On the nose toasted wood, vanilla, oak, dark chocolate, blackberries, black cherries.
The palate has fresh acidity (more than you need for this kind of wine), moderate concentration, and firm tannins that are ripe. Not much length though.
Overall this is a modern St Emilion with lots of oak influence, but still well integrated and pleasant.

M ruby. M- nose with earthiness and hints of leather, dark fruit and liquorice. M+ body, m- acidity and intensity. M finish and low tannins. Dark fruit, earthy and hits of leather and oak. Good wine but not from the best vintage so passed its peak I believe. If you have a bottle left, drink now!
More earthy from limestone. Dark chocolate or coffee nose. More balanced, good acidity. Still not enough at back of palate. Drink now.
As always, a 5 star for my favourite wine. Brings back memories of my visit to this vinyard in Saint Emilion several years ago.
Needed time to open after pulling the cork. Tannins still tight and finish is dry and chalky. Well balanced with good acidity. Red and black fruits with some savory character noted
A variation in the nose in 3 hrs, from spicy to red fruit and going to cedar fragrance. Medium to full body, medium tannin, with dry fruit flavor. Quite complex and good money wine.
Beautiful dark ruby colour. Delightfully peppery, light amounts of tannins and almost has a smokey aroma. An easy drink for any night as the finishing isnt too harsh nor it is too mellow.

Tasted in the cellars of Domaine Vacheron with one of the owner Denis Vacheron following the high recommendation of Alain B, Vivinoer from France.
They are a certified biodynamic producer.
This was a yummy pinot noir produced with grapes coming at 100% from the silex-clay terroir.
Deeper medium ruby color, the aromas of blackberry with some hints of vanilla and almond poking through. Some spices noted.
A beautiful softer tannins palate. Lasting.

What the.. red (!) sancerre! One of tonight’s discoveries! They really exist and aren’t bad either. Not a big fan of light wines, but this one had a straight way to the tastebuds. Good mix of strawberry, raspberry and sour cherry. Could even guess that it might be wine from Bourgogne - but this is so much more enjoyable. Red fruit is mostly dominant, but there is a small hint of licorice and tobacco hidden.

Wine tasting Wednesday at Restaurant Tyler, Sommelier Secret Stash week! This is a French Pinot Noir.  On the nose is cherry, mineral, and a hint of smoke. The flavor is bone dry full of earth and cherry.  In the back ground lots of licorice hints.  It finishes up with growing sweet aftertaste “ kind of “ cherry sweet tart candy.  Going 4.5 🍷!
Elegant, feminine Pinot Noir, full of cherry flavor.  Tastes like a reasonably priced Volnay.    An excellent value.

Very delicate sensual Pinot.

Raspberries, strawberries, cola, candied cherry, dried herbs, crushed rocks and chalky minerality, cinnamon. 
Palate of high acidity, medium alcohol, medium flavors intensity, low tannins. Flavors of raspberry, strawberry, salinity, chalkiness, cinnamon and anise like spice. A Spatburgunder like Pinot Noir from Sancerre!

This is a dry red wine made from the Pinot Noir grape, grown in Sancerre, France.
Aromas of orange zest, baking spices strawberry, smoke, oak, vanilla and mushroom.
Light to medium-bodied with notes of cherry, raspberry, blackberry oak, and baking spices on the palate.
Generous finish with fine-grained tannins and nervy acidity.

Clear, cool and utterly northern, this is obviously a labour of love and very clean and focussed: spider web tannin, so smooth, gentle, slightly misty red fruit and lovely damsen flavoured length. Lacks Burgundian complexity, but an idiosyncratic treat anyway.

4.3 ⭐️

👃 full of cherry and strawberry, hint of oak and mushroom. The earthy notes come forward as the wine breathes.

👅 Sour cherry, oak, wood chips. 

Perfect summer red! 🍷

2015 belle dame vintage. Clear medium ruby red. No gas or sediment. Fruity red and black cherry nose with evident new oak, vanilla cola, and hints of licorice. Dry. Light bodied, high acid. Low tannin but tasting slightly higher alcohol (13.5-14%). Tart cherry, some mint, and vanilla on the palate. Still young but great quality producer. Surprisingly on the more modern side of Sancerre pinot noir

let‘s start at this wine:

1st: cork closure, fortunately ok

2nd: color > a light & transparent red, no brown edges

3rd: nose > smoke, raspberries, lilac, pretty complex 

4th: palate > plums, very ripe raspberries, forest strawberries, medium+ length, good complexity 

5th: conclusion > I wouldn’t store this wine for too long anymore, the curve is stable st the moment, but will go down in the next 2 years.
but it was fun to try this wine!

Pale ruby. Medium viscocity.

Medium plus intensity of developing aromas. Rose, blossom, strawberry, cherry, cranberry, mushroom, damp earth, wet stone. Underripe fruit. High-toned aromas.

High complexity. High flavor intensity. Medium minus body. Low tannin. High acid. Medium alcohol (13% but would’ve said 12%).

Finish is long. Wine is outstanding. Can be drunk now or in 1-5 years.

Fine one, but needs a few more years, obviously. Light ruby red color. Elegantly fruity on the nose - forest berries, dried peaches and subtle cheesecake notes. Medium- body, young tannin, red berries, subtle earthiness🥂✨
Pale ruby color. Red fruit as well as some herbs showing from the glass. High acidity, but lack some structure for my taste. Fresh east drinking glass.
Light and good acidity. Initial nose with mushrooms and opened up very nicely to a lovely palate of strawberries

Pinot noir from the Loire, this Sancerre from the 2013 vintage is delicious. Very fruity style, yet rich deep and delicious. The nose is full of  raspberry, red fruit, cranberry, dried strawberry, blackcurrant,  black cherry, black fruit, dark fruit, gooseberry and a hint of geranium, the body medium with depth, round tannins, lovely acidity and fresh fruity finish. Very pleasant and delicious.

This is a very unusual and flat Pinot. It took 2 to 3 hours to open up to where we enjoyed it. Very smooth, earthy and light. Expensive and not our favorite.

Beautiful red and deep color. Biodynamie philosophy allows the vintner to express the best of his terroir in this beautiful wine. BELLES DAMES shows good concentration of red cherries and grey pepper aromas with Violet flower hints. Long finish. Outstanding!!

Savoury notes have slightly overtaken the strawberry fruit. This wine is standing at the verge of its autumn with an energy still well alive. That includes the tannins that are still a bit rough. Drink now, before the fruit dries out. Do have a meal near, it's no faint pinot...
Interesting discovery. Didn't know Sancerre made Pinot noirs...:had to try... Not disappointed.  Fresh cut strawberries.  Decent nose.

(Blind tasting challenge - Flight #1 Wine #2) Light body. High acidity. Strawberry, blood orange, mushroom. Medium aftertaste. Called Sancerre Rouge and got it right ✌️From the same winery I had my first Sancerre Rouge months ago.

Stephan Reinhardt for WA, Mar. 2021, 93/100: ‘opens remarkably aromatic and ripe, with stewed or baked fruit aromas on the nose, tending toward plums rather than berries and a touch of caramel. With more aeration, the wine gets more precise, more flinty and piquant and reveals fresh cherry and potted strawberry aromas. Silky on the palate opening, this is a full-bodied, rich intense and persistent Pinot Noir with impressive concentration, freshness and finesse.’ The best red I’ve ever had. 4.7.

It has transparent and watery garnet color and light body, dull, delicate fruit forward (but, should not be encouraged for decanting), oak, tobacco... Needed substantial patience for bottle breathing to enjoy subtle elegant bouque from Sancerre P.N. But, it's not much satisfactory (Maybe, I was a little hasty and careless for stabilization before uncorking) and, after the party, couldn't make me feel thirst enough to pick up another bottle later.

Not often I taste Sancerre Rouge so it was interesting for me to try this Belle Dame, Vacheron’s top cuvee from 50 yr old vines. Pinot Noir was more prominent in the Loire pre-phylloxera but was overtaken by Sauvignon Blanc since then, and hasn’t quite gained the fame of Cab Franc to be Loire’s top red varietal.

Crunchy raspberry fruit with astringent, drying tannins and searing acidity. A bit imbalanced and disjointed to me though some aeration would’ve helped. Hope my next glass will be better.

Tasted May 28 2016...fully expected it to be over the hill. Nothing of the sort! Clean translucent red color, no browning at all, immediately approachable on first tasting, over an hour only grew in warmth and richness. Medium to full bodied (this is a Sancerre Pinot, right? Hard to believe), with raspberries and blackberries fresh on the palate. Medium-full viscosity, yummy mouth feel, this wine exceeded the expectations of everyone in the room. Amazing. .

Note: Had this wine at a recent Chianti Consortium tasting, and poured to me by Sergio Zingarelli himself. This "Gran Selezione", is of his best fruit, and given the BDM treatment to help justify this new designations cost. Sergio is the head of the Chianti Consortium, and is tasked to educate the masses on the new Chianti hierarchy. Big structured Sangiovese with all the brute force of an Italian miners hands, big acids, tart red fruits and berries, smoke, and old wood with grippy tannins and a long finish.14.5%

Cliff lede doesn’t scrimp or cut the corner. Artisan wine with strong structure and balanced fruit. Sugars are tamed with a tannins but even the tannins are balanced showing careful consideration of making a deeply delicious and satisfying wine.

Beautiful yet again. Big and bold but smooth and well rounded. Drinking like a dream.
Incredible - velvet vanilla chocolate on the mid pallete, earthy leathery nose.

Young bright wine.  Clear deep color.  Light body wine floats and slippery.  Light plumb light cranberry hint of mint coffee and BlackBerry. Sharp pre-ripe fruit on the finish.   A very light wine for a Bordeaux blend deserves the Claret label over Bordeaux.

blackberries,  cassis, leather and earthy notes with oak on nose at open. inky purple color with a full mouth feel. same in taste with a hint of vanilla and firm tannins on the lingering finish at open. after an hour get a nice red cherry and some cedar.

Bing cherries, plums, blackberries and a layer of oak fill the nose. Smooth tannins overlay some smokiness and smooth dark fruit on the palate. The finish is moderate and this wine is fairly dry initially but mellows towards the finish. A nice wine, which I’d have again!

Decent wine. Unfortunately the nose offers much more than the palette. Wonderful aromas of oak, black fruit, and spices, but pretty light and a little thin on the palette. Would have been a 4.5+ if the palette matched the aromas
Four point five.  Had this first at the winery on our honeymoon.  Enjoyed this again for our first anniversary.  Just a bit too hot to get five stars.

This '14 vintage is great. I probably could of let this rest a few more years, it's still pretty tight right out of the bottle.

Great opulent nose of blackberry, black cherry, plum, cassis, and some notes of leather, cedar, and espresso. Palate matches with some smooth but tight tannins, great acidity, and a nice long fruit filled finish.
Lots of earthy notes and dark fruit. Not the typical California cab I would have expected but still delicious!
Love cliff lede claret. We joined the wine club for it. Wonderful richness with berries and earthy plant flavors, tobacco and spice.
Juicy on the front and dry on the back; stronger after aging.  Drank 12-17-21
Blueberry, clove and mellow on the nose. Silky cacao, loamy earthiness. Good astringency.
I like Cliff Lede with the modern Napa style but I think it is a bit over the top when it comes to baking spices. Still enjoyable.
Smooth and very approachable Claret. On the nose hints of tobacco, black fruit, and leather. Long evolving flavor on the palate. Pleasant with light apps before dinner. Decent QPR. Solid red blend.

This stuff is just so good!!!  It’s a silky and elegant Boudreaux blend. It’s tastes like the chocolate covered blueberries in the produce aisle. This flavor makes its way through other flavors of plum, black cherry, black licorice, and some wet cedar. The chocolate covered blueberries shine al the way through the long finish. I’m so glad that we were able to our hands on this one!
This is a really unique pour.  Two thumbs up. A solid 4.0.
earthy spicy very smooth. great napa red
Big bold beauty
4.2 stars.  Black fruit, tobacco, chocolate and oak.  Very smooth
Dark berries, very smooth, and Cliff Lede never disappoints.
Dark fruit and some tobacco notes.  Very enjoyable
Bordeaux blend Napa Style with big body and sharp and full tannins.  It’s a big and dry mouthfeel
Dark Plum balanced with sweet vanilla and other fruit flavors
Amazing bright nose, medium body, and fucking delicious!
2017 - Solid wine. Blend nonetheless fantastic juice. Dark ruby red color, lots of minerality and smooth finish. I would drink this all day.

Not bad! Nice Pinot Noir color. Earthy aromas. Dried cherries. Beautiful on the palate, but a harsh bitter finish.
On the ranch. Delish but gets better after breathing for a bit
4.5. Absolutely delicious! Beautiful oak. Plum. Blackberry. Vanilla. Amazing finish. So good. Had with chocolate tarrine.
Very enjoyable drink.  Paired with Christmas dinner and was surprised at how well everything worked together.  Definitely recommended.
Blueberries and fig jam on the nose. Intense vanilla, oak, and cocoa on the palate, with some pepper and lingering tannin.

2016 vintage. 4.3. Frankly, a stupid good deal given the sale on the cliff lede site right now. Tastes better than plenty of just fine 75+ dollar blends. Huge nose of blackberry and raspberry. Cherry. Cedar and cocoa. Palette is luscious w dark chocolate, smoke and dark fruit. Some vanilla and spice. High acid keeps this very fresh. Just wonderful.

Very open and welcoming bordeaux blend. Aromas of black currant, ripened black cherries, black plum. Hints of green peper increases complexity. Oak; toast, smoke, vanilla, clove, lilly. Nice hints of farmyard and gamey notes. Coffee. Palate is dry, med+ acid. High, moderately finegrained tannins which lasts. Full body. Pronounced flavour intensity and long finish. Balanced, complex. Drink now.
Figs and chocolate covered cherries. A nice winery in Napa.
Wow, this was delicious. Notes of chocolate.

Intense, rich bouquet.  Dark fruit and plum on the nose followed by wet earth and vanilla. The primary flavors are much more subtle.  Everything from the nose transfers to the flavor seamlessly. Acidity is medium and bright. Tannins are lighter than I expected from a blend of such usually intense grapes from Napa. Overall very happy with this well-balanced and excellently executed blend.

Second time tasting this Napa blend. Creamy, full bodied mouthfeel. Sharp tannins and tart, warm acidity. Boysenberry, wood and pepper on the nose. On the palate are flavors of dark fruit, vanilla, oak and chocolate.

4.75 - Absolutely delicious. Without question, the best French red wine I have ever had. First glass I was thinking 4.5, second glass I thought it was close to a 5. Light red colour with ruby gleams. Delicate nose on red fruits with cinnamon and pepper flavours. Complex on the palate with red berries and cherry notes with a great finesse. Lightly oaked and well-structured tannins, medium finish.

Tried at the tasting in the chateau. Premium cuvee of the chateau, with elegant and complicated aroma of species, parseley, dill, anis, pepper, cloves, backed by ripe cherries and chocolate. On the palate very deep, quite elegant and intensive, tanins are well integrated and balanced with acidity. The taste is very round and soft, with a lot of red fruits, cacao, and chocolate. Very elegant wine, we liked it very much, however, the PQR is not so great, we would prefer other chateau.

A great wine is a cathedral for the senses, and few can measure up to the power, sumptuous nature and harmonious presence of a finely crafted Chateauneuf-du-Pape from a memorable vintage. Whether the aptly named 'Val de Dieu' had something to do with it or not, this bottle sings hallelujahs in the glass, rebounding with penetrating depth and rich, luxurious notes of raspberry, black cherry, potpourri spice and vanilla, heralded by the rustle of silky tannins that further enhance the pure, sensual appeal.
Drinking more like a Bordeaux. Great fruit and not to 'raisiny' like many Chateauneuf-du-pape seem to be.

2017 vintage.  Dark ruby/purple color, forest fruit and kerosene on the nose.  Dark fruit, Asian spice, licorice, graphite on the palate.  I'm perplexed by the rave reviews. I can think of dozens of better Rhone wines for half the price.  89 points.

The Brechet Family owns five large wineries around the village of Chateuneuf du Pape in the south of the Rhone valley near Avignon. Their prime estate is the Chateau de Vaudieu, which is managed by the head of the family, Laurent Brechet. Three lines of red and two lines of white are produced here, with the Val de Dieu being the top wine. Dark berried with intense flavours of cherries and licorice. Soft tannins and fine acidity provide a silky sensation on the palate. Long and heavy finish.
Leather, raisins, firm tannins even after 11 years. Balanced and smooth. Quality wine making. A treat!

Very full bodied, grippy tannins  on opening.

Probably the most admirable wine I ever had, so many things going on in this bottle I don't know where to start. Black fruit, juicy, great structure, silky velvety tannins but still fresh, all so well blended together, I'm simply left speechless from this, and in some years it will even be better than now!

Great vintage and blend. 15% cab franc. 9% petit verdot. 21% Merlot. 55% Cab Sav. Wonderful nose with licorice. Black fruit with leather, new oak, cinnamon and marrow, with eternal finish. Enjoy meats and strong cheese n

Wow! Layers after layers of cassis, blueberries, black cherries, wood notes and tannins that start on the midpallet and travel from the front to back of the tongue. Full rich flavors together with a pronounced nose of forest floor, dried cherries and plums. Exceptional wine.

Shows a lush edge for the vintage, with raspberry preserves, blackberry paste and dark currant notes melded together, framed with a smoldering charcoal hint that glides through the velvety finish. A suave, modern rendition. Best from 2018.

Elegant red which deliver a perfumed nose. Crushed red fruits, crushed flowers and hints of vanilla.

Good texture and medium long finishing. Was eager to try after @[1|16425004|Vita in Vinum] review on it.
oak blackcurrant blackberry black fruit plum cassis chocolate strong tannins but integrated good balance and long mouthfeel

Red berries, beautiful.

Nose slight dusty at first, then opens up to share dark berries cassis fresh tobacco
Full body, with rich tanins
Most enjoyable
Really good - great example of a French Bordeaux wine and drank well all night.
Lovely dry, full body, high tannis with hints of blackberry, plum and black fruits
Heavy, dark berry nose that lingers. Strong bold tannins. Drank the 2011 with duck pate and filet... perfect! Could lay down for 10 more years.
Trending more towards red fruits spectrum, elegant rather than powerful. The unforced and less extracted approach probably suits the vintage well
Sensational. Third growth goodness. Consumed with M, Jan and Diana in Greyton.
Really nice and mature well balanced with good body and nose

Pretty persuasion (R.E.M.) Picked up this robust, full-bodied and deep garnet red Bordeaux at my local supermarket as ‘a bargain’ for € 35 and opened it… probably years too soon. The nose was welcoming me with plum, licorice and oak but on the palate it was still a bit tight, dry and tannin-driven. After a while more and more aromas and flavors of violets, spice and blackberries came through and the finish got longer by the minute long. Still I’m not persuaded to buy this one again.

Dry, high acidity, high tannins, full body, oaked

Wonderful chateau, pungent on the nose in fact so much so it fills the room, earthy aromas and first sip of dark fruit and an aftertaste of chocolate blueberry

Fantastic Bordeaux, smooth and velvet, full of wonderful dark berries and a good  cherryness, slight notes of licorice, solid wooden elegant tannins, very long on the palate, voluminous nose, wholesome body, takes time (and a decanter) to open

Amazing potential. Dark ruby with some nuance of garnet in color. Very friendly and approachable medium strong elegant body structure. Attack of the aromas of black currant and bouquet of chocolate. Hints of licorice, violet, pear and oak on the nose. On the palate, its expressive robustness, finess and soft tannins assure me of its potential.

Delicious palate with high fruit, tannin and alcohol, decent length to the finish and a silky mouthfeel.

Nose: Evolved from violet, blueberry, raspberry, mushroom to blackcurrant, plum, earthy, vanilla, toasty, meaty and sweet spices like cinnamon, clove and white pepper.
Palate: A little harsh tannins at first, but turn to be softer after aeration. Medium high acidity. Bold, strong but not yet gorgeous, extremely intensive fruity, sweet spicy and savoury flovour with good structure and integrated wood characters.

I gave this wine a second chance, as the first bottle turned out to be slightly corked, now I can say this is a good wine, exactly what you expect to get from Margaux Grand Cru Classe, depth, rich flavor, elegant medium body, moderate acidity, and moderate tannins, the bouquet is impressive, clove, forest bed, earth, moss, black currant, fig, oak, kiwi, dark chocolate, leather, needs decanting at least couple of hours, goes well with medium steak.
Dark fruit nose with a little woodiness. Long mouth feel.

spicy, mahogany on the nose of this ruby red claret. wonderful depth; silky smooth finish. tastes of truffles, turmeric, blackberries with a hint of cassis on the palat. the 2011 vintage is just right fir drinking now
